Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>A few comments...
>
>First, normalizing weights is not really feasible.  The relative
>values of the weights does *not* scale because the sigmoid function is
>absolute, i.e. it would not be scaled along with the weights.  If you
>try to normalize weights based on the relative strengths you will
>eliminate the functionality of the network.
>  
>
Fair point.. You would have to scale the activation function by the same 
amount as the weights in order to maintain a network's functionality.

>Second, with a simple network like XOR, it looks fine to have the
>weights go up unbounded, and indeed the original NEAT was distributed
>without such a cap.  But once you start evolving networks with
>hundreds of connections or more, it doesn't work the way you guys are
>thinking.  A connection that evolves to "drown out" other connections
>then can never be surmounted.  In other words, new connections have no
>chance of having an effect, since they are drowned out as soon as they
>appear, so you stop getting new functionality.
>
>Now one thing you can do about this perhaps is find the max and min
>weights in the network and generate all new connections within that
>range.  However, that will cause the weights of the entire network to
>gradually gravitate to larger and larger magnitudes, which also means
>it will becomes a binary network.
>  
>

Yes I see. Also, allowing the weight range to gradually increase is 
equivalent to what I described above - normalizing the weights and 
scaling the activation function by the same amount. This has the effect 
of compressing the sigmoid so that eventually it becomes so steep that 
it describes a step function (binary network). If you were to scale the 
other way then the sigmoid becomes linear, it would describe the graph 
y=x or some variation on it.

>I think the right thing to do for long runs that are producing very
>complex networks is indeed to cap the weights.  This also means it is
>easier to break out of a local optimum, depending on the weight
>mutation power.
>  
>
I agree.

Now, you could perhaps cause the same 'drowing-out' effect late on in a 
search if you used a parameterized activation function and added the 
parameters to the search. But I agree that the drown-out effect's 
usefulness is questionable and perhaps even undesirable, + parameterized 
actiavtion functions just increase to size of the search space... a lot.

Colin.
